title: Pandharpur: The Southern Kashi
short_description: Join the Wari pilgrimage to worship Lord Vithoba on the banks of Chandrabhaga.
long_description:
Pandharpur in Maharashtra is the seat of the Varkari tradition, a devotional movement emphasizing simplicity, love, and equality. The deity here is Vithoba (or Vitthal), a form of Lord Krishna standing on a brick with hands on his hips, waiting for his devotee Pundalik. 

The town is synonymous with the 'Wari', an annual pilgrimage where lakhs of devotees (Varkaris) walk hundreds of kilometers from Alandi and Dehu to Pandharpur, singing Abhangas (hymns) of Saints Dnyaneshwar and Tukaram. This ocean of humanity, carrying saffron flags and clashing cymbals, culminates in Pandharpur on Ashadi Ekadashi.

The temple of Lord Vitthal is unique because it allows 'Pad sparsh' darshanâ€”devotees can rest their heads on the feet of the Lord's idol, a rare intimacy allowed in Hindu temples (though queues for this can take 24 hours!). The Chandrabhaga river (Bhima river) flowing in a crescent shape adds to the sanctity.
spiritual_significance: The Kashi of the South. It represents the Bhakti movement. The 'Pad sparsh' darshan is considered the ultimate blessing. It unites all castes in devotion.

major_temples_and_sites.name: Vitthal-Rukmini Temple
major_temples_and_sites.description: The main shrine. The idol of Vithoba is self-manifested sand stone.

major_temples_and_sites.name: River Chandrabhaga
major_temples_and_sites.description: The holy river where pilgrims bathe. It is shaped like a crescent moon (Chandra).

major_temples_and_sites.name: Pundalik Temple
major_temples_and_sites.description: A temple dedicated to Pundalik, the devotee for whom Krishna came and waited on a brick.

major_temples_and_sites.name: Vishnupad Temple
major_temples_and_sites.description: Located on the river bed, housing footprints of Lord Krishna and cow hooves.

major_temples_and_sites.name: Gopalpur
major_temples_and_sites.description: A nearby site associated with Krishna's cow-herding pastimes.

rituals_and_experiences: Pad-sparsh Darshan (touching the feet generated of the Idol).
Participate in the Bhajan/Kirtan with Varkaris.
Visit the Samadhis of saints like Namdev and Chokhamela near the temple steps.
Walk on the sandy river bed.
highlights: The intense Bhakti (devotion) of the Varkaris.
The unique standing posture of the idol.
The historic architecture of the temple.
best_months: July (Ashadi Ekadashi) and Nov (Kartiki Ekadashi) are peak. Aug-Feb is good for normal visits.
how_to_reach: By Air: Pune Airport (200km). By Train: Pandharpur Station. By Road: 4 hours from Solapur or 5 hours from Pune.
stay_recommendations: Luxury: None. Spiritual: Bhakta Niwas (huge complex built by Temple Trust). Budget: Local lodges.
safety_tips: crowds during Ekadashi are overwhelming (millions); avoid if claustrophobic. The queue for Pad-sparsh can take 20+ hours; Mukh Darshan (view from distance) is faster.
sample_itinerary:
Day 1: Arrive. Bath in Chandrabhaga. Visit Pundalik Temple. Mukh Darshan of Vithoba (2-3 hours). Dinner.
Day 2: Visit Vishnupad Temple and Gopalpur. Attend any Kirtan in the town. Depart.
